DOC.HEAD: Exposure to Cold Kills 75 in India, Bangladesh
DOC.TEXT: At least 75 people, many of them homeless, have died of exposure to cold overnight temperatures in northern India and Bangladesh during the last three days, news reports said Saturday. Temperatures plummeted to near freezing, chilling people who have little in the way of clothing or shelter to cope with the brief winter in this normally hot, sunny region. At least nine more deaths were reported Friday in Bangladesh, bringing the toll to 44 since Wednesday, newspapers in Dhaka said. In India, 20 people have died of the cold in northern Bihar state since Wednesday night, United News of India reported from Patna, the state capital. Seven people, including four homeless people, died of cold in the same period in neighboring Uttar Pradesh state, Press Trust of India said. It added that many birds were found dead of cold in the fields. Gujarat state reported four deaths, Press Trust said. The mercury dipped to 38 degrees, the lowest temperature of the season, in New Delhi on Friday night and to 41 in Bihar and northern Bangladesh. Midday highs this week have reached the low 60s, but many people, even those with shelter, are ill-equipped to cope with the overnight temperatures. Most of Bangladesh's 110 million people live in houses with mud floors and walls made of thin straw mats. In both countries, the homeless sleep on the ground, with the luckier ones wrapped in blankets. Some kindle small fires with scavenged scraps of paper.
